coredata.dc:title: Sliding suffix tree
coredata.dc:publisher:
MDPI AG
Postfach Basel CH-4005
indexing@mdpi.com

abstract.ce:para: We consider a sliding windowW over a stream of characters from some alphabet of constant size. We want to look up a pattern in the current sliding window content and obtain all positions of the matches. We present an indexed version of the sliding window, based on a suffix tree. The data structure of size Θ(|W|) has optimal time queries Θ(m + occ) and amortized constant time updates, where m is the length of the query string and occ is its number of occurrences.

xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency: Center for Outcomes Research and Evaluation, Yale School of Medicine
Javna Agencija za Raziskovalno Dejavnost RS

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: Funding: The work is partially supported by the Slovenian Research Agency (research core funding No. P2-0359 and N2-0053).

affiliation.organization: Faculty of Computer and Information Science
Faculty of Computer and Information Science

grantlist.grant-text: We would like to thank anonymous reviewers of Combinatorial Pattern Matching 2018 for valuable references to the related work and their ideas for simplifying the queries without using the lowest common ancestor auxiliary data structures used in the previous version of this paper [34]. The work is partially supported by the Slovenian Research Agency (research core funding No. P2-0359 and N2-0053).

abstract.ce:para: We consider a sliding windowW over a stream of characters from some alphabet of constant size. We want to look up a pattern in the current sliding window content and obtain all positions of the matches. We present an indexed version of the sliding window, based on a suffix tree. The data structure of size Θ(|W|) has optimal time queries Θ(m + occ) and amortized constant time updates, where m is the length of the query string and occ is its number of occurrences.
